questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she feels well. Her first child was born via cesarean delivery because of fetal macrosomia. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her current medications include folic acid and a prenatal vitamin. She is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); her prepregnancy BMI was 30 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a fundal height of 28 cm. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of 27 cm and no evidence of fetal anomalies. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasonography of the fetal arteries can be used to diagnose hemolytic disease of the fetus, which can cause hydrops fetalis and is associated with polyhydramnios. However, hydrops fetalis is associated with ultrasound findings of ascites, pleural effusions, pericardial effusions, and/or skin edema, none of which are present in this patient's ultrasound. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up during this patient's next routine prenatal visit in 4 weeks would be indicated if her examination at this time showed no abnormalities. This patient's transvaginal ultrasound findings are consistent with polyhydramnios, which requires further evaluation and management.

C) CORRECT:

The two most common identifiable causes of polyhydramnios are fetal abnormalities and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Given the absence of any fetal abnormalities on transvaginal ultrasonography and the presence of several risk factors for GDM (e.g., obesity, fetal macrosomia during a previous pregnancy), this patient's polyhydramnios is most likely caused by GDM. Therefore, a GDM screening test is recommended at this time.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends GDM screening in all pregnant patients between 24–28 weeks' gestation; early screening (prior to 24 weeks) is recommended in women with risk factors for GDM. GDM can be diagnosed using a one- or two-step oral glucose challenge test.

D) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA testing is typically used for the prenatal screening of common fetal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 21, trisomy 18), which can be associated with polyhydramnios. However, this patient's ultrasound at 24 weeks' gestation shows no fetal abnormalities, so fetal aneuploidies are unlikely. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis can be used to evaluate for fetal genetic abnormalities, hemolytic anemia, and infection, all of which can be associated with polyhydramnios. This patient's transvaginal ultrasound shows no fetal abnormalities, hydrops fetalis, or signs of fetal distress, so these diagnoses are unlikely. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.
questions.hint: A large uterine size for gestational age (i.e., fundal height (in cm) that exceeds the gestational age (in weeks) between 24 and 36 weeks' gestation) and an amniotic fluid index (AFI) ≥ 24 cm indicate polyhydramnios.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old gravida 4, para 3 woman presents at 30 weeks’ gestation for a prenatal check. She is dyspneic and is unable to sleep at night.
Her vital signs are normal. She has a normal heart rate and rhythm with no murmurs. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Her abdomen is dull to percussion and distended beyond what is expected at 30 weeks’ gestation. There is no pedal edema. Cervical examination reveals a closed os.
An ultrasound reveals severe polyhydramnios but is otherwise unremarkable; the fetus is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Plan for elective cesarean section at 33 weeks’ gestation
Continue to monitor the pregnancy with a weekly nonstress test
Recommend maternal fluid restriction to no more than 1500 mL per day

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elective cesarean section is not indicated for women with severe polyhydramnios.

B) INCORRECT:

Progesterone does not reduce amniotic fluid production.

C) CORRECT:

This pregnancy has been complicated by polyhydramnios, a condition characterized by an abnormally large volume of amniotic fluid. Amniotic fluid volume can be assessed by ultrasound using either the amniotic fluid index (AFI) or the deepest vertical pocket (DVP). The AFI is the sum of the maximum vertical amniotic fluid pocket diameters (not containing umbilical cord or fetal extremities) from each of the four quadrants. A normal AFI at term is between 5 cm and 24 cm (total). A total AFI <5 cm suggests oligohydramnios and ≥24 cm suggests polyhydramnios. In clinical practice, the DVP is increasingly preferred over the AFI to evaluate amniotic fluid volume. A depth <2 cm suggests oligohydramnios, a depth of 2 to 8 cm is considered normal, and a depth >8 cm suggests polyhydramnios.

Approximately 70% of cases of polyhydramnios are idiopathic; the other possible etiologies are congenital or genetic disorders, maternal diabetes, multiple gestation, isoimmunization, and congenital anomalies.

Complications of polyhydramnios include preterm prelabor rupture of membranes, preterm delivery, fetal malpresentation, increased frequency of cesarean delivery, fetal death in utero, and neonatal death. Mild, idiopathic polyhydramnios can be monitored with routine prenatal care. In individuals with moderate to severe polyhydramnios, antepartum fetal surveillance (e.g., with serial nonstress tests or biophysical profiles) may be considered.

Severe polyhydramnios that causes maternal respiratory distress should be immediately treated with reduction amniocentesis. Excess amniotic fluid often reaccumulates quickly, so repeat amnioreduction is typically necessary. Women at less than 34 weeks' gestation should receive a course of glucocorticoids before the amnioreduction, to maximize fetal pulmonary maturity in case the procedure precipitates a preterm birth.

Other interventions to manage polyhydramnios in the antenatal period have been described, including case series using indomethacin. Although indomethacin does reduce the amniotic fluid volume, there are concerns about neonatal risks with this medication, such that it is no longer recommended for the sole purpose of reducing amniotic fluid volume in the setting of polyhydramnios.

Key learning point: The treatment that is indicated for maternal respiratory distress due to severe polyhydramnios is amnioreduction.

D) INCORRECT:

Mild-to-moderate polyhydramnios can be monitored, without intervention, by serial nonstress testing and biophysical profiles that assess fetal well-being.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women with polyhydramnios should remain well hydrated.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old primigravida at 31 weeks gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine prenatal visit. She has no significant past medical history and denies medication use. On examination, her fundal height measures 36 cm. Ultrasound reveals an amniotic fluid index of 28 cm and a normal fetal heart rate. The fetus has normally formed kidneys with a filled bladder, but the cranial vault is not visualized, although the face is seen.
Which fetal condition is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral renal agenesis results in absent kidneys, leading to oligohydramnios due to reduced urine production. Ultrasound would show nonvisualization of kidneys and an absent or small bladder. The findings of normally formed kidneys, a filled bladder, and increased amniotic fluid index are inconsistent with bilateral renal agenesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves cause lower urinary tract obstruction, typically in male fetuses, leading to a distended bladder and potential hydronephrosis. This condition often results in oligohydramnios due to reduced fetal urine output. The ultrasound findings of normal renal anatomy, a filled bladder, and increased amniotic fluid index are inconsistent with posterior urethral valves. Additionally, the absence of the cranial vault is unrelated to urinary tract obstructions.

C) CORRECT:

Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect resulting from the failure of closure of the anterior neuropore, leading to the absence of the cranial vault and significant portions of the brain. The ultrasound findings of a normal fetal heart rate, normally formed kidneys, and a filled bladder indicate intact renal development and function, differentiating this condition from renal causes of polyhydramnios. The visualization of facial structures without the cranial vault is a classic marker for anencephaly. This defect impairs fetal swallowing, reducing the normal decrease in amniotic fluid volume and contributing to polyhydramnios. Maternal folate deficiency is a known risk factor for neural tube defects like anencephaly.

Key learning point: Polyhydramnios can be caused by fetal conditions that impair swallowing or increase urine production, such as anencephaly, while conditions like posterior urethral valve and maternal NSAID use are associated with oligohydramnios.

D) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia causes polyhydramnios due to impaired fetal swallowing and presents with the 'double bubble' sign on ultrasound. However, it does not affect cranial development, and the fetal skull is fully formed. The inability to visualize the cranial vault, despite normal facial structures and functional kidneys and bladder, indicates a neural development issue, not gastrointestinal obstruction.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine prenatal check. She has a history of gestational diabetes controlled with diet. Over the past month, she has noticed increasing abdominal distension and occasional difficulty breathing. On examination, her fundal height measures 34 cm. Fetal heart sounds are present. Ultrasound reveals a single fetus with a significantly increased amniotic fluid index.
Which of the following best accounts for her exam findings?

choices.text: Excess maternal fluid intake raising amniotic fluid volume
Preeclampsia-related fluid overload in the amniotic sac
Decreased fetal swallowing secondary to oropharyngeal anomaly
Excessive fetal urine output from maternal hyperglycemia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amniotic fluid volume is regulated by fetal urine production and swallowing, not maternal fluid intake. The placenta controls water and solute transfer, preventing significant changes in amniotic fluid volume from maternal hydration. Moderate variations in maternal fluid intake do not affect amniotic fluid balance.

B) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria due to endothelial dysfunction, not increased amniotic fluid. It often results in oligohydramnios due to compromised placental perfusion. Amniotic fluid volume is primarily determined by fetal urine output, not maternal fluid shifts seen in preeclampsia.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased fetal swallowing due to oropharyngeal anomalies, like esophageal atresia, can cause polyhydramnios. However, the ultrasound does not show structural anomalies, and the patient's gestational diabetes is a recognized cause of polyhydramnios through fetal hyperglycemia and polyuria.

D) CORRECT:

In gestational diabetes, elevated maternal glucose levels cross the placenta, causing fetal hyperglycemia. This leads to osmotic diuresis and increased fetal urine production, which is the main contributor to amniotic fluid volume in late pregnancy. The result is polyhydramnios, presenting as increased fundal height and symptoms like abdominal distension and respiratory discomfort. Tight glycemic control is crucial to prevent polyhydramnios and its complications.

Key learning point: Increased fundal height in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes is most commonly due to polyhydramnios, which is an excess of amniotic fluid often associated with poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for routine antenatal care. She reports increasing abdominal size and occasional shortness of breath for the past two weeks. Her records note inconsistent dietary adherence and recurrent elevated fingerstick glucose readings. Examination shows a symphysiofundal height four centimeters above expected for her gestational age. Ultrasound confirms a markedly elevated amniotic fluid index, with a structurally normal fetus.
Which mechanism most likely accounts for this patient's clinical findings?

choices.text: Fetal cardiac failure resulting in hydrops fetalis
Excessive fetal urine output from hyperglycemia-induced osmotic diuresis
Decreased fetal swallowing secondary to esophageal malformation
Increased amniotic fluid production due to intra-amniotic infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrops fetalis from cardiac failure presents with fetal edema and effusions, indicating structural or myocardial issues. The ultrasound shows a structurally normal fetus, and the context of maternal hyperglycemia suggests polyuria-induced polyhydramnios, not cardiac failure.

B) CORRECT:

In uncontrolled maternal diabetes, elevated maternal glucose crosses the placenta, causing fetal hyperglycemia. The fetal pancreas increases insulin production, but insulin does not counteract the osmotic effects of high glucose levels. This hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis in the fetal kidneys, increasing urine output. Since amniotic fluid is primarily fetal urine in later pregnancy, this results in polyhydramnios. This mechanism underscores the importance of maternal glycemic control in regulating amniotic fluid volume.

Key learning point: Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus is a common cause of polyhydramnios due to fetal hyperglycemia and polyuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Polyhydramnios due to decreased fetal swallowing is typically associated with esophageal atresia, where ultrasound would show structural anomalies like an absent stomach bubble. The ultrasound in this case shows a structurally normal fetus, excluding esophageal malformation as a cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Intra-amniotic infections, such as chorioamnionitis, present with fever, uterine tenderness, and inflammatory signs, which are absent here. The elevated amniotic fluid index with a normal fetus suggests a metabolic cause, not infection.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old G3P2 woman at 38 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with a sudden gush of clear fluid per vagina. She has documented polyhydramnios and was undergoing routine antenatal monitoring. On speculum examination, her cervix is 3 cm dilated without active bleeding, and she shows no signs of maternal distress. Fetal heart tracing shows a persistent rate of 70 beats per minute for over two minutes.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the persistent fetal bradycardia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maternal hypotension can reduce uteroplacental perfusion, potentially leading to fetal bradycardia. However, this patient shows no signs of hypotension, such as dizziness or pallor, and her stable condition makes this cause unlikely. The presence of polyhydramnios and sudden fluid loss suggests a different mechanism for fetal compromise.

B) CORRECT:

Umbilical cord prolapse occurs when the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting fetal part, often after membrane rupture. In polyhydramnios, the excess amniotic fluid prevents proper fetal head engagement, increasing the risk of cord prolapse. The cord can become compressed between the fetal head and maternal pelvis, disrupting blood flow and oxygen delivery to the fetus. This results in persistent fetal bradycardia due to decreased oxygenation.

Key learning point: Polyhydramnios increases the risk of cord prolapse after membrane rupture, which can lead to persistent fetal bradycardia due to cord compression.

C) INCORRECT:

Vasa previa involves fetal vessels crossing the cervical os, which can rupture during membrane rupture, causing fetal blood loss and bradycardia. It typically presents with vaginal bleeding, which is absent here. The clear fluid and lack of bleeding make vasa previa unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Placental abruption causes fetal bradycardia due to compromised oxygen delivery from premature placental separation. It usually presents with pain, uterine tenderness, and bleeding, none of which are present here. The clear fluid and absence of maternal distress argue against abruption.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 35 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department with progressive abdominal discomfort, dyspnea when lying flat, and lower extremity edema. She denies contractions, bleeding, or recent illness.Vital signs are BP, 124/76 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 20; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); SpO₂, 97% on room air. ECG is normal. Physical examination reveals significant uterine distension and bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. Fetal heart tones are present at 150 bpm. Bedside ultrasound shows a single fetus in cephalic presentation, normal cardiac activity, and an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order lower extremity venous Doppler ultrasound
Aspirate 200 ml of amniotic fluid to alleviate maternal discomfort and arrange next day follow-up with obstetrics
Organize urgent fetal MRI and arrange outpatient obstetrics follow up with results
Obtain an echocardiogram and refer urgently to cardiology

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inferior vena cava thrombosis is rare and typically associated with central venous devices or thrombophilia. In late pregnancy, bilateral edema is common, and in this case, the distended uterus with elevated amniotic fluid index points to polyhydramnios as the more likely cause.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — An amniotic fluid index (AFI) > 24 cm confirms the diagnosis of polyhydramnios, which is commonly associated with maternal diabetes, fetal anomalies, and multiple gestation. The patient's abdominal distension and dyspnea are likely due to elevated intra-abdominal pressure from uterine overdistension. Emergency management includes prompt obstetric consultation to assess for structural fetal abnormalities, evaluate maternal glycemic control, and monitor for complications such as preterm labor or umbilical cord prolapse.

C) INCORRECT:

Amnioreduction is an invasive procedure performed under controlled conditions by maternal-fetal medicine specialists. It is not initiated in the ED and carries risks of preterm labor and infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal MRI may aid in the evaluation of underlying structural anomalies contributing to polyhydramnios, but it is neither a first-line modality nor appropriate for emergent assessment in the emergency department.

E) INCORRECT:

While dyspnea and lower extremity edema in late pregnancy raise concern for cardiomyopathy, this patient has normal oxygen saturation, no pulmonary findings, and an ultrasound consistent with polyhydramnios, not cardiac dysfunction. Cardiopulmonary causes are less likely than uterine overdistension from excess amniotic fluid.
